questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the code from the bottom onto the box where the code is missing to complete this API request against the Cisco SD-WAN vManage Statistics API, which specifies a device with an Id of 100faff9-8b36-4312-bf97-743b26bd0211, a local color of biz-internet, and a remote color of gold. Not all options are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Same question as 38.
Answers: deviceID=,&local-color=,&remote-color
Note: Quoutes are optional, more important are the commas.

comments.content:
Wocilon from the past is wrong, Wocilon of the present is here! 
Answer:
deviceId=
&local-color=
&remote-color=

Quotes are optional, equal signs are mandatory, and commas are NOT needed.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Cisco SD-WAN deployment must be fixed using vManage APIs. A call to vEdge Hardware Health API returns the data in the exhibit (only a portion is shown). If the JSON shown in the exhibit is converted to a Python dictionary named `d`, how is the `status` property referenced?

discussion.content:
Same question as 74.
Answer is D but is missing all quoutes

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A. d['data']['statusList']['status'].

When the JSON data is converted to a Python dictionary d, the status property is correctly referenced as d['data']['statusList']['status']. This format corresponds to the nested keys in the JSON structure. The other options are incorrect.

Selected Answer: D
The answer is D, just needs quotes around 'data', 'statusList', and 'status'
>> d['data'][0]['statusList'][0]['status']

Right! the correct answer is really D, however it's missing quotes tested in Python3 as well:
>>> d['data'][0]['statuslist'][0]['status']
'up'
all others gives errors and since question is how is the 'status' property referenced? the less wrong answer from the list is really D!

duplication with few other questions, correct answer is A, 
d['data']['statusList']['status']

Selected Answer: C
or C - replace curly brakets with square ones .. LOL

Answers are wrong.
Correct answer:
login_credentials = {'j_username':'admin', 'j_password':'admin'}
response = session.post(url=login_url, data=login_credentials, verify=False)

Note: There is a missing header with "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded"
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/sdwan/#!authentication/how-to-authenticate

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the code from the bottom onto the box where the code is missing to perform the login operation and security check on the vManage web server at the specified IP address. Not all code options are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

choices.D: The device goes offline while you poll the API dashboard.
choices.B: The rate limit of the Cisco Meraki API is exceeded.
choices.A: The wrong API key is used to query the data.

questions.question_text: A configuration has been made to add to every switch port a new port description. The script worked initially, but after a few seconds, an HTTP 429 status code was received. What causes this error message from the Meraki cloud?

discussion.content: B - The HTTP 429 Too Many Requests response status code indicates the user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time ("rate limiting")
correction - B is the correct answer

Selected Answer: B
Remember that lists in Python are zero indexed to neighbors[1] is the SECOND element.

Selected Answer: B
Access to position [1] of the list, i.e. 's2' (while 's1' is position [0])
Yes, B is the correct Answer
Wouldn't S1 actually be in the 0 spot and S2 is actually 1?. So yes, B.

comments.content: No, B is correct. First object will be 0, so S2 will be object 1 in the list.
